column1: Cuautitlán Izcalli (Spanish pronunciation: [kwawtiˈtlan isˈkaʎi]) is a city and municipality in the north of State of Mexico
column2: Mexico. The name comes from Náhuatl and means 'your house among the trees.'

column1: By 2005 Mexican national intermediary (conteo) census figures
column2: the city of Cuautitlán Izcalli is the sixth-most populous in the state
the city of Cuautitlán Izcalli has governing jurisdiction over the following communities: Axotlán
column3: Ej. Sta. Ma. Tianguistenco (Ej. el Rosario)
column8: and San Pablo de los Gallos

column1: The second-largest community in the municipal area of 109.9 square kilometres (42.4 sq mi) is the town of Huilango.
It is bordered by the municipalities of Cuautitlán
Cuautitlán Izcalli municipality was created in the 1970s
column2: carved mostly out of Cuautitlán de Romero Rubio (now simply 'Cuautitlán'). Originally planned as the first self-sufficient city in the neighbourhood of Mexico City
column3: the city's design was based on European and American cities and included an industrial
column4: a residential and several green areas. After the 1985 Mexico City earthquake
column6: the plans fell apart due to a large influx of people searching for zones

column1: Nowadays almost 75% of the municipality's residents work in nearby cities such as Satellite City and Mexico City
column2: causing enormous congestion on the only highway available

column1: Several shopping malls have opened in recent years
column5: which compete with Perinorte to the south of the municipality. There is a Ford Motor Company plant

column1: Cuautitlán Izcalli is home of the Centro Episcopal Mexicano visited by Pope John Paul II during his 1991 visit to the country.  You can find the largest San Benedict's Abbey in Mexico and the second largest music auditorium
column3: in the urban area of Mexico City.
took part in the discussions leading to the Constitution of 1917
column4: under the rule of Venustiano Carranza. He was exiled in 1923.
